News that AI Engineers can use from today is Nano Banana 2, which is more formally called 3.1 Flash Image. The big story is the pricing: it is rated the #1 image model in the world per Arena and Artificial Analysis, and yet costs half the price (At $67/1k images, vs Nano Banana Pro ($134/1k) and GPT Image 1.5 ($133/1k) for generation, and FLUX.2 [max] at $140/1k images for editing).

  • Arena/Artificial Analysis results + pricing signal: Multiple evaluators report Nano Banana 2 taking #1 Text-to-Image and strong editing placements, while undercutting "Pro" pricingâ€”e.g., $67 / 1k images cited by Artificial Analysis vs ~$133â€“134 for GPT Image 1.5 and Nano Banana Pro (ArtificialAnlys, arena, kimmonismus). This is also a reminder that leaderboards are becoming product levers: "day-0" integrations (e.g., fal) and prompt packs/templates ship alongside eval wins (GeminiApp templates, GoogleAI prompts).

Agentic coding + productized "tasks", memory, and evals (and the backlash against complexity)

æ™ºèƒ½ä½“ç¼–ç  + äº§å“åŒ–çš„"ä»»åŠ¡"ã€è®°å¿†ä¸è¯„ä¼°ï¼ˆä»¥åŠå¯¹å¤æ‚æ€§çš„åå¼¹ï¼‰

  • Agents "just work" more often now, but still fail off-distribution: Several practitioners describe a step change in reliability/utility for coding agents across recent frontier models (e.g., GPT-5.2 / GPT-5.3 Codex, Opus 4.6, Gemini 3.1), shifting from "proof of concept" to something like delegating CLI work to juniors (teortaxesTex, paul_cal). Others caution that advanced ML/data engineering remains brittle off-distribution (michalwols, MParakhin).

Agents "just work" more often now, but still fail off-distribution: Several practitioners describe a step change in reliability/utility for coding agents across recent frontier models (e.g., GPT-5.2 / GPT-5.3 Codex, Opus 4.6, Gemini 3.1), shifting from "proof of concept" to something like delegating CLI work to juniors (teortaxesTex, paul_cal). Others caution that advanced ML/data engineering remains brittle off-distribution (michalwols, MParakhin).

  • "Tasks" as the new packaging layer: Microsoft's Copilot Tasks pitches "talk less, do more" delegation with user-visible plans and control, in "research preview" (mustafasuleyman, yusuf_i_mehdi).

  • Persistent memory becomes table stakesâ€”and introduces interoperability pain: A widely shared update claims Claude rolled out auto-memory ("remembers what it learns across sessions") (trq212), echoed in the Claude ecosystem (omarsar0). Developers immediately hit workflow friction when memory/state lives in tool-specific hidden directories (hurting "multi-agent, multi-tool" continuity) (borisdayma).

æŒä¹…è®°å¿†æˆä¸ºåŸºæœ¬è¦æ±‚â€”â€”å¹¶å¼•å…¥äº’æ“ä½œæ€§ç—›ç‚¹ï¼šä¸€ä»½å¹¿æ³›ä¼ æ’­çš„æ›´æ–°ç§°Claudeæ¨å‡ºäº†è‡ªåŠ¨è®°å¿†ï¼ˆauto-memoryï¼‰åŠŸèƒ½ï¼ˆ"è®°ä½è·¨ä¼šè¯å­¦ä¹ çš„å†…å®¹"ï¼‰ï¼ˆtrq212ï¼‰ï¼Œåœ¨Claudeç”Ÿæ€ç³»ç»Ÿä¸­å¾—åˆ°å‘¼åº”ï¼ˆomarsar0ï¼‰ã€‚å½“è®°å¿†/çŠ¶æ€å­˜åœ¨äºå·¥å…·ç‰¹å®šçš„éšè—ç›®å½•ä¸­æ—¶ï¼Œå¼€å‘è€…ç«‹å³é‡åˆ°å·¥ä½œæµæ‘©æ“¦ï¼ˆæŸå®³"å¤šæ™ºèƒ½ä½“ã€å¤šå·¥å…·"è¿ç»­æ€§ï¼‰ï¼ˆborisdaymaï¼‰ã€‚

Persistent memory becomes table stakesâ€”and introduces interoperability pain: A widely shared update claims Claude rolled out auto-memory ("remembers what it learns across sessions") (trq212), echoed in the Claude ecosystem (omarsar0). Developers immediately hit workflow friction when memory/state lives in tool-specific hidden directories (hurting "multi-agent, multi-tool" continuity) (borisdayma).

åŸæ ‡é¢˜: METRâ€™s Joel Becker on exponential Time Horizon Evals, Threat Models, and the Limits of AI Productivity

AIE Europe CFPand AIE Worldâ€™s Fairpaper submissions for CAISpeer review are due TODAY - do not delay! Last call ever.

AIE Europeä¼šè®®å¾ç¨¿å¯äº‹ï¼ˆCFPï¼ŒCall for Papersï¼‰å’ŒAIE Worldâ€™s Fairï¼ˆAIEä¸–ç•Œåšè§ˆä¼šï¼‰è®ºæ–‡æäº¤ç»™CAISï¼ˆäººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½å®‰å…¨ä¸­å¿ƒï¼ŒCenter for AI Safetyï¼‰åŒè¡Œè¯„å®¡çš„æˆªæ­¢æ—¥æœŸå°±åœ¨ä»Šå¤©â€”â€”ä¸è¦æ‹–å»¶ï¼è¿™æ˜¯æœ€åé€šçŸ¥ã€‚

Weâ€™re excited to welcome METR for their first LS Pod, hopefully the first of many:

æˆ‘ä»¬å¾ˆé«˜å…´æ¬¢è¿METRï¼ˆæ¨¡å‹è¯„ä¼°ä¸å¨èƒç ”ç©¶ç»„ç»‡ï¼‰é¦–æ¬¡åšå®¢LS Podï¼ˆLatent Spaceæ’­å®¢ï¼‰ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›è¿™æ˜¯å¤šæ¬¡åˆä½œä¸­çš„ç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡ï¼š

METR are keepers of currently thesingle most infamous chart in AI:

METRç›®å‰ä¿ç®¡ç€AIé¢†åŸŸæœ€è‡­åæ˜­è‘—çš„ä¸€å¼ å›¾è¡¨ï¼š

But every Latent Space reader should be sophisticated enough to know that the details matter and that hype and hyperbole go hand in hand in AI social media, because the millions of impressions that got, by people who donâ€™t understand or care about the nuances, disclaimers, and error bars, far outreaches the 69k views on the corrections by the people who actually made the chart:

ä½†æ¯ä½Latent Spaceçš„è¯»è€…éƒ½åº”è¯¥è¶³å¤Ÿæˆç†Ÿï¼Œæ˜ç™½ç»†èŠ‚è‡³å…³é‡è¦ï¼Œä¸”ç‚’ä½œä¸å¤¸å¼ åœ¨AIç¤¾äº¤åª’ä½“ä¸Šæ€»æ˜¯ç›¸ä¼´è€Œè¡Œï¼Œå› ä¸ºé‚£äº›ä¸ç†è§£æˆ–ä¸å…³å¿ƒç»†å¾®å·®åˆ«ã€å…è´£å£°æ˜å’Œè¯¯å·®çº¿ï¼ˆerror barsï¼‰çš„äººå¸¦æ¥çš„æ•°ç™¾ä¸‡æ¬¡æ›å…‰ï¼Œè¿œè¿œè¶…è¿‡äº†å®é™…åˆ¶ä½œè¯¥å›¾è¡¨çš„äººæ‰€å‘å¸ƒçš„æ›´æ­£å†…å®¹è·å¾—çš„6.9ä¸‡æ¬¡æµè§ˆï¼š

Thereâ€™s a lot of nuance both in making benchmarks (as we discoveredwith OpenAI on our SWE-Bench Verified podcast) and in extrapolating results from them, especiallywhere exponentials and sigmoids are concerned. METRâ€™s Long Horizons work itself has known biases that the authors have responsibly disclosed, but go far too underappreciated in the pursuit of doomer chart porn.

If youâ€™re interested in a short, sharable TED talk version of this pod, over at AIE CODE we were blessed to feature Joel twice, as astage talkand with a longer formsmall workshop with Q&A:

I've been collectingHTTP range tricksfor a while now, and I decided it would be fun to build something with them myself that used binary search against a large file to do something useful.

æˆ‘ä¸€ç›´åœ¨æ”¶é›† HTTP èŒƒå›´è¯·æ±‚æŠ€å·§ï¼ˆHTTP range tricksï¼‰ï¼Œç°åœ¨å†³å®šç”¨è¿™äº›æŠ€å·§è‡ªå·±æ„å»ºä¸€ä¸ªæœ‰è¶£ä¸”å®ç”¨çš„å·¥å…·â€”â€”é€šè¿‡äºŒåˆ†æŸ¥æ‰¾ï¼ˆbinary searchï¼‰åœ¨å¤§å‹æ–‡ä»¶ä¸­å®šä½æ•°æ®ã€‚

So Ibrainstormed with Claude. The challenge was coming up with a use case for binary search where the data could be naturally sorted in a way that would benefit from binary search.

äºæ˜¯æˆ‘å’Œ Claude è¿›è¡Œäº†å¤´è„‘é£æš´ã€‚æŒ‘æˆ˜åœ¨äºæƒ³å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªé€‚åˆäºŒåˆ†æŸ¥æ‰¾çš„ç”¨ä¾‹ï¼Œè¦æ±‚æ•°æ®èƒ½å¤Ÿä»¥å¤©ç„¶æœ‰åºçš„æ–¹å¼æ’åˆ—ï¼Œä»è€Œå‘æŒ¥äºŒåˆ†æŸ¥æ‰¾çš„ä¼˜åŠ¿ã€‚

One of Claude's suggestions was looking up information about unicode codepoints, which means searching through many MBs of metadata.

Claude ç»™å‡ºçš„å»ºè®®ä¹‹ä¸€æ˜¯æŸ¥è¯¢ Unicode ç ç‚¹ï¼ˆunicode codepointsï¼‰ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€éœ€è¦åœ¨æ•°å…†å­—èŠ‚çš„å…ƒæ•°æ®ä¸­è¿›è¡Œæœç´¢ã€‚

I had Claude write me a spec to feed to Claude Code -visible here- then kicked off anasynchronous research projectwith Claude Code for web against mysimonw/researchrepo to turn that into working code.

æˆ‘è¯· Claude ç¼–å†™äº†ä¸€ä»½æŠ€æœ¯è§„èŒƒï¼ˆspecï¼‰ä¾› Claude Code ä½¿ç”¨â€”â€”å¯åœ¨æ­¤å¤„æŸ¥çœ‹â€”â€”éšåé’ˆå¯¹æˆ‘çš„ simonw/research ä»“åº“ï¼Œä¸ Claude Code for web å¯åŠ¨äº†ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥ç ”ç©¶é¡¹ç›®ï¼ˆasynchronous research projectï¼‰ï¼Œå°†å…¶è½¬åŒ–ä¸ºå¯è¿è¡Œçš„ä»£ç ã€‚

Here's theresulting report and code. One interesting thing I learned is that Range request tricks aren't compatible with HTTP compression because they mess with the byte offset calculations. I added'Accept-Encoding': 'identity'to thefetch()calls but this isn't actually necessary because Cloudflare and other CDNs automatically skip compression if acontent-rangeheader is present.

I deployed the resultto my tools.simonwillison.net site, after first tweaking it to query the data via range requests against a CORS-enabled 76.6MB file in an S3 bucket fronted by Cloudflare.

æˆ‘å°†ç»“æœéƒ¨ç½²åˆ°äº† tools.simonwillison.net ç«™ç‚¹ï¼Œåœ¨æ­¤ä¹‹å‰å…ˆè¿›è¡Œäº†è°ƒæ•´ï¼Œä½¿å…¶é€šè¿‡èŒƒå›´è¯·æ±‚æŸ¥è¯¢å­˜å‚¨åœ¨ S3 å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ä¸­ã€ç”± Cloudflare åŠ é€Ÿçš„ã€å·²å¯ç”¨ CORSï¼ˆè·¨åŸŸèµ„æºå…±äº«ï¼‰çš„ 76.6MB æ–‡ä»¶ã€‚

The demo is fun to play with - type in a single character like Ã¸ or a hexadecimal codepoint indicator like 1F99C and it will binary search its way through the large file and show you the steps it takes along the way:

item.description:
æ ‡ç­¾: #æ™ºèƒ½ä½“ç¼–ç¨‹ #Rust #æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ 

æ‘˜è¦: ä¸€ååŸæœ¬è´¨ç–‘AIç¼–ç¨‹èƒ½åŠ›çš„å¼€å‘è€…ï¼Œåœ¨å€ŸåŠ©Opus/Codexç­‰æ™ºèƒ½ä½“å·¥å…·å¼€å‘Rustæœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ åº“çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­å‘ç°ï¼Œæœ€æ–°ä¸€ä»£AIæ¨¡å‹çš„ç¼–ç¨‹èƒ½åŠ›å·²å®ç°æ•°é‡çº§çªç ´ï¼Œèƒ½å¤Ÿé«˜æ•ˆå®Œæˆä»¥å¾€éœ€è¦æ•°æœˆæ‰èƒ½ç‹¬ç«‹å®Œæˆçš„å¤æ‚å·¥ç¨‹ä»»åŠ¡ã€‚

åŸæ ‡é¢˜: An AI agent coding skeptic tries AI agent coding, in excessive detail

An AI agent coding skeptic tries AI agent coding, in excessive detail

ä¸€ä½AIæ™ºèƒ½ä½“ç¼–ç¨‹ï¼ˆAI agent codingï¼‰æ€€ç–‘è®ºè€…äº²è‡ªå°è¯•AIæ™ºèƒ½ä½“ç¼–ç¨‹ï¼Œäº‹æ— å·¨ç»†åœ°è®°å½•å…¨è¿‡ç¨‹

It would be arrogant to port Python'sscikit-learnâ€” the gold standard of data science and machine learning libraries â€” to Rust with all the features that implies.But that's unironically a good idea so I decided to try and do it anyways. With the use of agents, I am now developingrustlearn(extreme placeholder name), a Rust crate that implements not only the fast implementations of the standard machine learning algorithms such aslogistic regressionandk-means clustering, but also includes the fast implementations of the algorithms above: the same three step pipeline I describe above still works even with the more simple algorithms to beat scikit-learn's implementations.

å°†Pythonçš„scikit-learnâ€”â€”æ•°æ®ç§‘å­¦ä¸æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ åº“çš„é»„é‡‘æ ‡å‡†ï¼ˆgold standardï¼‰â€”â€”ç§»æ¤åˆ°Rustï¼Œå¹¶ä¿ç•™å…¶å…¨éƒ¨åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œè¿™å¬èµ·æ¥å¾ˆç‹‚å¦„ã€‚ä½†è¿™å¹¶éè®½åˆºï¼ˆunironicallyï¼‰ï¼Œç¡®å®æ˜¯ä¸ªå¥½ä¸»æ„ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘å†³å®šæ— è®ºå¦‚ä½•éƒ½è¦å°è¯•ã€‚å€ŸåŠ©æ™ºèƒ½ä½“ï¼ˆagentsï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ‘æ­£åœ¨å¼€å‘rustlearnï¼ˆæåº¦ä¸´æ—¶çš„åç§°ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªRust crateï¼Œä¸ä»…å®ç°äº†é€»è¾‘å›å½’ï¼ˆlogistic regressionï¼‰å’ŒKå‡å€¼èšç±»ï¼ˆk-means clusteringï¼‰ç­‰æ ‡å‡†æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ ç®—æ³•çš„é«˜æ•ˆå®ç°ï¼Œè¿˜åŒ…å«äº†ä¸Šè¿°ç®—æ³•çš„é«˜æ•ˆå®ç°ï¼šå³ä½¿å¯¹äºæ›´ç®€å•çš„ç®—æ³•ï¼Œæˆ‘æ‰€æè¿°çš„ä¸Šè¿°ä¸‰æ­¥æµç¨‹ä»ç„¶é€‚ç”¨ï¼Œè¶³ä»¥å‡»è´¥scikit-learnçš„å®ç°ã€‚

It would be arrogant to port Python'sscikit-learnâ€” the gold standard of data science and machine learning libraries â€” to Rust with all the features that implies.

å°†Pythonçš„scikit-learnâ€”â€”æ•°æ®ç§‘å­¦ä¸æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ åº“çš„é»„é‡‘æ ‡å‡†ï¼ˆgold standardï¼‰â€”â€”ç§»æ¤åˆ°Rustï¼Œå¹¶ä¿ç•™å…¶å…¨éƒ¨åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œè¿™å¬èµ·æ¥å¾ˆç‹‚å¦„ã€‚

But that's unironically a good idea so I decided to try and do it anyways. With the use of agents, I am now developingrustlearn(extreme placeholder name), a Rust crate that implements not only the fast implementations of the standard machine learning algorithms such aslogistic regressionandk-means clustering, but also includes the fast implementations of the algorithms above: the same three step pipeline I describe above still works even with the more simple algorithms to beat scikit-learn's implementations.

Max also captures the frustration of trying to explain how good the models have got to an existing skeptical audience:

Maxï¼ˆMax Woolfï¼‰è¿˜æ•æ‰åˆ°äº†è¯•å›¾å‘æŒæ€€ç–‘æ€åº¦çš„å—ä¼—è§£é‡Šæ¨¡å‹å·²ç»å˜å¾—å¤šä¹ˆå‡ºè‰²æ—¶çš„æŒ«è´¥æ„Ÿï¼š

The real annoying thing aboutOpus 4.6/Codex 5.3 is that it's impossible to publicly say "Opus 4.5 (and the models that came after it) are an order of magnitude better than coding LLMs released just months before it" without sounding like an AI hype booster clickbaiting, but it's the counterintuitive truth to my personal frustration. I have been trying to break this damn model by giving it complex tasks that would take me months to do by myself despite my coding pedigree but Opus and Codex keep doing them correctly.
